episodes.subtitle: The Montgomery Bus Boycott, the South African divestment campaign, Chick-fil-A! Almost anyone can launch a boycott, and the media loves to cover them. But do boycotts actually produce the change they're fighting for?
episodes.description: The Montgomery Bus Boycott, the South African divestment campaign, Chick-fil-A! Almost anyone can launch a boycott, and the media loves to cover them. But do boycotts actually produce the change they're fighting for?
episodes.title: Do Boycotts Work?

episodes.subtitle: Experts and pundits are notoriously bad at forecasting, in part because they aren't punished for bad predictions. Also, they tend to be deeply unscientific. The psychologist Philip Tetlock is finally turning prediction into a science -- and now even you
episodes.description: Experts and pundits are notoriously bad at forecasting, in part because they aren't punished for bad predictions. Also, they tend to be deeply unscientific. The psychologist Philip Tetlock is finally turning prediction into a science -- and now even you could become a superforecaster.
episodes.title: How to Be Less Terrible at Predicting the Future

episodes.subtitle: Discrimination can't explain why women earn so much less than men. If only it were that easy.
episodes.description: Discrimination can't explain why women earn so much less than men. If only it were that easy.
episodes.title: The True Story of the Gender Pay Gap

episodes.subtitle: Sure, we all want to make good personal decisions, but it doesn't always work out. That's where "temptation bundling" comes in.

episodes.subtitle: The argument for open borders is compelling -- and deeply problematic.
episodes.description: The argument for open borders is compelling -- and deeply problematic.
episodes.title: Is Migration a Basic Human Right?

episodes.subtitle: One woman's quest to find the best burger in town can teach all of us to eat smarter.
episodes.description: One woman's quest to find the best burger in town can teach all of us to eat smarter.
episodes.title: The Cheeseburger Diet

episodes.subtitle: He was handed the keys to the global economy just as it started heading off a cliff. Fortunately, he'd seen this movie before.
episodes.description: He was handed the keys to the global economy just as it started heading off a cliff. Fortunately, he'd seen this movie before.
episodes.title: Ben Bernanke Gives Himself a Grade

episodes.subtitle: Even a brutal natural disaster doesn't diminish our appetite for procreating. This surely means we're heading toward massive overpopulation, right? Probably not.
episodes.description: Even a brutal natural disaster doesn't diminish our appetite for procreating. This surely means we're heading toward massive overpopulation, right? Probably not.
episodes.title: Why Do People Keep Having Children? (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: In our collective zeal to reform schools and close the achievement gap, we may have lost sight of where most learning really happens -- at home.
episodes.description: In our collective zeal to reform schools and close the achievement gap, we may have lost sight of where most learning really happens -- at home.
episodes.title: Does “Early Education” Come Way Too Late?

episodes.subtitle: Lessons from Tom Petty's rise and another rocker's fall.
episodes.description: Lessons from Tom Petty's rise and another rocker's fall.
episodes.title: Should Everyone Be in a Rock Band?

episodes.subtitle: A kitchen wizard and a nutrition detective talk about the perfect hamburger, getting the most out of garlic, and why you should use vodka in just about everything.
episodes.description: A kitchen wizard and a nutrition detective talk about the perfect hamburger, getting the most out of garlic, and why you should use vodka in just about everything.

episodes.subtitle: Researchers are trying to figure out who gets bored - and why - and what it means for ourselves and the economy. But maybe there's an upside to boredom?
episodes.description: Researchers are trying to figure out who gets bored - and why - and what it means for ourselves and the economy. But maybe there's an upside to boredom?

episodes.description: The process is famously secretive (and conducted in Swedish!) but we pry the lid off at least a little bit.
episodes.title: How To Win A Nobel Prize

episodes.subtitle: When one athlete turned pro, his mom asked him for $1 million. Our modern sensibilities tell us she doesn't have a case. But should she?
episodes.description: When one athlete turned pro, his mom asked him for $1 million. Our modern sensibilities tell us she doesn't have a case. But should she?
episodes.title: Should Kids Pay Back Their Parents for Raising Them?

episodes.subtitle: Anne-Marie Slaughter was best known for her adamant views on Syria when she accidentally became a poster girl for modern feminism. As it turns out, she can be pretty adamant in that realm as well.
episodes.description: Anne-Marie Slaughter was best known for her adamant views on Syria when she accidentally became a poster girl for modern feminism. As it turns out, she can be pretty adamant in that realm as well.

episodes.subtitle: Suspenders may work better, but the dork factor is too high. How did an organ-squeezing belly tourniquet become part of our everyday wardrobe -- and what other suboptimal solutions do we routinely put up with?
episodes.description: Suspenders may work better, but the dork factor is too high. How did an organ-squeezing belly tourniquet become part of our everyday wardrobe -- and what other suboptimal solutions do we routinely put up with?

episodes.title: “I Don't Know What You've Done With My Husband, But He's a Changed Man.”

episodes.subtitle: Conventional programs tend to be expensive, onerous, and ineffective. Could something as simple (and cheap) as cognitive behavioral therapy do the trick?
episodes.description: Conventional programs tend to be expensive, onerous, and ineffective. Could something as simple (and cheap) as cognitive behavioral therapy do the trick?

episodes.description: We seem to have decided that ethnic food tastes better when it's served by people of that ethnicity (or at least something close). Does this make sense -- and is it legal?

episodes.description: Sure, markets generally work well. But for some transactions -- like school admissions and organ transplants -- money alone can't solve the problem. That's when you need a market-design wizard like Al Roth.

episodes.subtitle: If you are driving and kill a pedestrian, there's a good chance you'll barely be punished. Why?
episodes.description: If you are driving and kill a pedestrian, there's a good chance you'll barely be punished. Why?
episodes.title: The Perfect Crime

episodes.subtitle: When it comes to exercising outrage, people tend to be very selective. Could it be that humans are our least favorite animal?
episodes.description: When it comes to exercising outrage, people tend to be very selective. Could it be that humans are our least favorite animal?
episodes.title: Which Came First, the Chicken or the Avocado?

episodes.subtitle: Imagine that both substances were undiscovered until today. How would we think about their relative risks?
episodes.description: Imagine that both substances were undiscovered until today. How would we think about their relative risks?
episodes.title: What’s More Dangerous: Marijuana or Alcohol?

episodes.subtitle: Unlike certain elected officials in Washington, mayors all over the country actually get stuff done. So maybe we should ask them to do more?
episodes.description: Unlike certain elected officials in Washington, mayors all over the country actually get stuff done. So maybe we should ask them to do more?
episodes.title: “If Mayors Ruled the World”

episodes.subtitle: The war on cigarettes has been fairly successful in some places. But 1 billion humans still smoke -- so what comes next?
episodes.description: The war on cigarettes has been fairly successful in some places. But 1 billion humans still smoke -- so what comes next?
episodes.title: How to Make People Quit Smoking

episodes.subtitle: Thinking of Bitcoin as just a digital currency is like thinking about the Internet as just e-mail. Its potential is much more exciting than that.
episodes.description: Thinking of Bitcoin as just a digital currency is like thinking about the Internet as just e-mail. Its potential is much more exciting than that.
episodes.title: Why Everybody Who Doesn’t Hate Bitcoin Loves It

episodes.subtitle: In many ways, the gender gap is closing. In others, not so much. And that's not always a bad thing.
episodes.description: In many ways, the gender gap is closing. In others, not so much. And that's not always a bad thing.
episodes.title: Women Are Not Men (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: A psychology professor argues that the brain's greatest attribute is knowing what other people are thinking. And that a Queen song, played backwards, can improve your mind-reading skills.
episodes.description: A psychology professor argues that the brain's greatest attribute is knowing what other people are thinking. And that a Queen song, played backwards, can improve your mind-reading skills.
episodes.title: “It’s Fun to Smoke Marijuana”

episodes.subtitle: Yes, it expands the mind but we usually don't retain much -- and then there's the opportunity cost.
episodes.description: Yes, it expands the mind but we usually don't retain much -- and then there's the opportunity cost.
episodes.title: Is Learning a Foreign Language Really Worth It?

episodes.subtitle: In most countries, houses get more valuable over time. In Japan, a new buyer will often bulldoze the home. We'll tell you why.
episodes.description: In most countries, houses get more valuable over time. In Japan, a new buyer will often bulldoze the home. We'll tell you why.
episodes.title: Why Are Japanese Homes Disposable?

episodes.subtitle: The consequences of our low marriage rate -- and if the old model is less attractive, how about a new one?
episodes.description: The consequences of our low marriage rate -- and if the old model is less attractive, how about a new one?
episodes.title: Why Marry? (Part 2)

episodes.subtitle: The myths of modern marriage.
episodes.description: The myths of modern marriage.
episodes.title: Why Marry? (Part 1)

episodes.subtitle: Thick markets, thin markets, and the triumph of attributes over compatibility. This episode is included in the Freakonomics #smartbinge podcast playlist at wnyc.org/smartbinge
episodes.description:
Thick markets, thin markets, and the triumph of attributes over compatibility.

This episode is included in the Freakonomics #smartbinge podcast playlist at wnyc.org/smartbinge
episodes.title: What You Don’t Know About Online Dating

episodes.subtitle: The "beauty premium" is real, for everyone from babies to NFL quarterbacks.
episodes.description: The "beauty premium" is real, for everyone from babies to NFL quarterbacks.
episodes.title: Reasons to Not Be Ugly

episodes.subtitle: The benefits of rumor-mongering
episodes.description: The benefits of rumor-mongering
episodes.title: Everybody Gossips (and That’s a Good Thing)

episodes.subtitle: What "Sleep No More" and the Stanford Prison Experiment tell us about who we really are.
episodes.description: What "Sleep No More" and the Stanford Prison Experiment tell us about who we really are.
episodes.title: Fear Thy Nature (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: Dubner and Levitt talk about fixing the post office, putting cameras in the classroom, and wearing hats.
episodes.description: Dubner and Levitt talk about fixing the post office, putting cameras in the classroom, and wearing hats.
episodes.title: Are We Ready to Legalize Drugs? And Other FREAK-Quently Asked Questions

episodes.subtitle: Most people blame lack of time for being out of shape. So maybe the solution is to exercise more efficiently.
episodes.description: Most people blame lack of time for being out of shape. So maybe the solution is to exercise more efficiently.
episodes.title: What’s the “Best” Exercise?

episodes.subtitle: A commitment device forces you to be the person you really want to be. What could possibly go wrong?
episodes.description: A commitment device forces you to be the person you really want to be. What could possibly go wrong?
episodes.title: Save Me From Myself (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: The Pope just gave it to the global economy with both barrels. Was he right to do so?
episodes.description: The Pope just gave it to the global economy with both barrels. Was he right to do so?
episodes.title: Pontiff-icating on the Free-Market System

episodes.subtitle: It’s easy to get that idea. But is the stereotype true?
episodes.description: It’s easy to get that idea. But is the stereotype true?
episodes.title: Are Gay Men Really Rich?

episodes.subtitle: More than 1 million people die worldwide each year from traffic accidents. But there's never been a safer time to drive.
episodes.description: More than 1 million people die worldwide each year from traffic accidents. But there's never been a safer time to drive.
episodes.title: The Most Dangerous Machine

episodes.subtitle: It's time to do away with feel-good stories, gut hunches, and magical thinking.
episodes.description: It's time to do away with feel-good stories, gut hunches, and magical thinking.
episodes.title: Fighting Poverty With Actual Evidence

episodes.subtitle: Spontaneous order is everywhere if you know where to look for it.
episodes.description: Spontaneous order is everywhere if you know where to look for it.
episodes.title: What Do Skating Rinks, Ultimate Frisbee, and the World Have in Common?

episodes.subtitle: The online universe doesn't have nearly as many rules, or rulemakers, as the real world. Discuss.
episodes.description: The online universe doesn't have nearly as many rules, or rulemakers, as the real world. Discuss.
episodes.title: Who Runs the Internet?

episodes.subtitle: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?
episodes.description: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?
episodes.title: Freakonomics Goes to College, Part 2 (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: What's a college degree really worth these days?
episodes.description: What's a college degree really worth these days?
episodes.title: Freakonomics Goes to College, Part 1 (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: Being green is rarely a black-and-white issue -- but that doesn't stop marketers and politicians from pretending it is.
episodes.description: Being green is rarely a black-and-white issue -- but that doesn't stop marketers and politicians from pretending it is.
episodes.title: Why Bad Environmentalism Is Such an Easy Sell

episodes.subtitle: We spend billions on our pets, and one of the fastest-growing costs is pet "aftercare." But are those cremated remains you got back really from your pet?
episodes.description: We spend billions on our pets, and one of the fastest-growing costs is pet "aftercare." But are those cremated remains you got back really from your pet?
episodes.title: The Troubled Cremation of Stevie the Cat

episodes.subtitle: The science of what works -- and doesn't work -- in fund-raising
episodes.description: The science of what works -- and doesn't work -- in fund-raising
episodes.title: How to Raise Money Without Killing a Kitten

episodes.subtitle: Dubner and Levitt field your queries in this latest installment of our FREAK-quently Asked Questions.
episodes.description: Dubner and Levitt field your queries in this latest installment of our FREAK-quently Asked Questions.
episodes.title: How to Think About Money, Choose Your Hometown, and Buy an Electric Toothbrush

episodes.subtitle: A 19th-century Georgia land lottery may have something to teach us about today's income inequality.
episodes.description: A 19th-century Georgia land lottery may have something to teach us about today's income inequality.
episodes.title: Would a Big Bucket of Cash Really Change Your Life?

episodes.subtitle: Think you know how much parents matter? Think again. Economists crunch the numbers to learn the ROI on child-rearing.
episodes.description: Think you know how much parents matter? Think again. Economists crunch the numbers to learn the ROI on child-rearing.
episodes.title: The Economist’s Guide to Parenting (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: Once upon a time, office workers across America lived in fear of a dreaded infirmity. Was the computer keyboard really the villain -- and did carpal tunnel syndrome really go away?
episodes.description: Once upon a time, office workers across America lived in fear of a dreaded infirmity. Was the computer keyboard really the villain -- and did carpal tunnel syndrome really go away?
episodes.title: Whatever Happened to the Carpal Tunnel Epidemic?

episodes.subtitle: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.
episodes.description: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.
episodes.title: The Suicide Paradox (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: It's impossible to say for sure, but the Lebanese do remarkably well. Why?
episodes.description: It's impossible to say for sure, but the Lebanese do remarkably well. Why?
episodes.title: Who Are the Most Successful Immigrants in the World?

episodes.subtitle: Human beings love to predict the future, but we're quite terrible at it. So how about punishing all those bad predictions?
episodes.description: Human beings love to predict the future, but we're quite terrible at it. So how about punishing all those bad predictions?
episodes.title: The Folly of Prediction (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: Chicago has given the world more than sausage, crooked politics, and Da Bears.
episodes.description: Chicago has given the world more than sausage, crooked politics, and Da Bears.
episodes.title: The Middle of Everywhere

episodes.subtitle: We worship the tradition of handing off a family business to the next generation. But is that really such a good idea?
episodes.description: We worship the tradition of handing off a family business to the next generation. But is that really such a good idea?
episodes.title: The Church of "Scionology" (Rebroadcast)

episodes.subtitle: Even American parents have a strong "son preference" -- which means that a newborn daughter can be bad news for a marriage.
episodes.description: Even American parents have a strong "son preference" -- which means that a newborn daughter can be bad news for a marriage.
episodes.title: Do Baby Girls Cause Divorce?

episodes.subtitle: You know the saying: a winner never quits and a quitter never wins. To which Freakonomics Radio says ... Are you sure?
episodes.description: You know the saying: a winner never quits and a quitter never wins. To which Freakonomics Radio says ... Are you sure?
episodes.title: REBROADCAST: The Upside of Quitting

episodes.subtitle: The Encyclopedia of Ethical Failures catalogs the fiscal, sexual, and mental lapses of federal workers -- all with an eye toward preventing the next big mistake.
episodes.description: The Encyclopedia of Ethical Failures catalogs the fiscal, sexual, and mental lapses of federal workers -- all with an eye toward preventing the next big mistake.
episodes.title: Government Employees Gone Wild

episodes.subtitle: Is junk food an abomination or a modern miracle?
episodes.description: Is junk food an abomination or a modern miracle?
episodes.title: A Burger a Day

episodes.subtitle: What does "Pride and Prejudice" have to do with nuclear deterrence?
episodes.description: What does "Pride and Prejudice" have to do with nuclear deterrence?
episodes.title: Jane Austen, Game Theorist

episodes.subtitle: What happens to your reputation when you're no longer around to defend it?
episodes.description: What happens to your reputation when you're no longer around to defend it?
episodes.title: REBROADCAST: Legacy of a Jerk

episodes.subtitle: You might think that someone with a 50-50 chance of getting a fatal disease would want to know for sure -- but you would be wrong. What does this say about our supposed thirst for certainty?
episodes.description: You might think that someone with a 50-50 chance of getting a fatal disease would want to know for sure -- but you would be wrong. What does this say about our supposed thirst for certainty?
episodes.title: Do You Really Want to Know Your Future?

episodes.subtitle: Yet another reason to blame your parents for pretty much everything.
episodes.description: Yet another reason to blame your parents for pretty much everything.
episodes.title: Why Family and Business Don’t Mix

episodes.subtitle: It's awkward, random, confusing -- and probably discriminatory too.
episodes.description: It's awkward, random, confusing -- and probably discriminatory too.
episodes.title: Should Tipping be Banned?

episodes.subtitle: A glimpse into our driverless future.
episodes.description: A glimpse into our driverless future.
episodes.title: Baby, You Can Program My Car

episodes.subtitle: Dubner and Levitt talk about circadian rhythms, gay marriage, autism, and whether "pay what you want" is everything it's cracked up to be.
episodes.description: Dubner and Levitt talk about circadian rhythms, gay marriage, autism, and whether "pay what you want" is everything it's cracked up to be.
episodes.title: Can You Be Too Smart for Your Own Good? And Other FREAK-quently Asked Questions

episodes.subtitle: If any other product failed 94 percent of the time, you'd probably stop using it. So why do we put up with burglar alarms?
episodes.description: If any other product failed 94 percent of the time, you'd probably stop using it. So why do we put up with burglar alarms?
episodes.title: REBROADCAST: The Hidden Cost of False Alarms

episodes.subtitle: A look at whether spite pays -- and if it even exists.
episodes.description: A look at whether spite pays -- and if it even exists.
episodes.title: What Do Medieval Nuns and Bo Jackson Have in Common?

episodes.subtitle: Why is unemployment still so high? It may be because of something that happened well before the Great Recession.
episodes.description: Why is unemployment still so high? It may be because of something that happened well before the Great Recession.
episodes.title: It’s Crowded at the Top

episodes.subtitle: An interview with Unabomber Ted Kaczynski, whose younger brother turned him in -- and what it says about the Boston bombers.
episodes.description: An interview with Unabomber Ted Kaczynski, whose younger brother turned him in -- and what it says about the Boston bombers.
episodes.title: Running to Do Evil

episodes.subtitle: In many states, it is perfectly legal to not hire someone who smokes. Should employers also be able to weed out junk-food lovers or motorcyclists -- or anyone who wants to have a baby?
episodes.description: In many states, it is perfectly legal to not hire someone who smokes. Should employers also be able to weed out junk-food lovers or motorcyclists -- or anyone who wants to have a baby?
episodes.title: Help Wanted. No Smokers Need Apply

episodes.subtitle: A kid's name can tell us something about his parents -- their race, social standing, even their politics. But is your name really your destiny?
episodes.description: A kid's name can tell us something about his parents -- their race, social standing, even their politics. But is your name really your destiny?
episodes.title: How Much Does Your Name Matter?

episodes.subtitle: Real tax reform may or may not ever happen. In the meantime, how about making the current system work a bit better?
episodes.description: Real tax reform may or may not ever happen. In the meantime, how about making the current system work a bit better?
episodes.title: The Tax Man Nudgeth

episodes.subtitle: Freakonomics asks a dozen smart people for their best ideas. Get ready for a fat tax, a sugar ban, and a calorie-chomping tapeworm.
episodes.description: Freakonomics asks a dozen smart people for their best ideas. Get ready for a fat tax, a sugar ban, and a calorie-chomping tapeworm.
episodes.title: 100 Ways to Fight Obesity

episodes.subtitle: The NCAA basketball tournament grabs a lot of eyeballs, but turning them into dollars hasn't always been easy -- even when the "talent" is playing for free.
episodes.description: The NCAA basketball tournament grabs a lot of eyeballs, but turning them into dollars hasn't always been easy -- even when the "talent" is playing for free.
episodes.title: How Money Is March Madness?

episodes.subtitle: There ain't no such thing as a free parking spot. Somebody has to pay for it -- and that somebody is everybody.
episodes.description: There ain't no such thing as a free parking spot. Somebody has to pay for it -- and that somebody is everybody.
episodes.title: Parking Is Hell

episodes.subtitle: Sure, we all like to hear compliments. But if you're truly looking to get better at something, it's the negative feedback that will get you there.
episodes.description: Sure, we all like to hear compliments. But if you're truly looking to get better at something, it's the negative feedback that will get you there.
episodes.title: When Is a Negative a Positive?

episodes.subtitle: In many ways, the gender gap is closing. In others, not so much. And that's not always a bad thing.
episodes.description: In many ways, the gender gap is closing. In others, not so much. And that's not always a bad thing.
episodes.title: Women Are Not Men

episodes.subtitle: The gas tax doesn't work well, and it's only going to get worse. What's next?
episodes.description: The gas tax doesn't work well, and it's only going to get worse. What's next?
episodes.title: The Downside of More Miles Per Gallon

episodes.subtitle: No one wants mass shootings. Unfortunately, no one has a workable plan to stop them either.
episodes.description: No one wants mass shootings. Unfortunately, no one has a workable plan to stop them either.
episodes.title: How to Think About Guns

episodes.subtitle: It is startlingly easy to create false memories, especially in politics.
episodes.description: It is startlingly easy to create false memories, especially in politics.
episodes.title: Sure, I Remember That

episodes.subtitle: Levitt and Dubner go deep on "Freakonomics Experiments," a new research project that lets you take a chance on life.
episodes.description: Levitt and Dubner go deep on "Freakonomics Experiments," a new research project that lets you take a chance on life.
episodes.title: Would You Let a Coin Toss Decide Your Future?

episodes.subtitle: Steve Levitt has a novel idea for helping people make tough decisions
episodes.description: Steve Levitt has a novel idea for helping people make tough decisions
episodes.title: Introducing “Freakonomics Experiments”

episodes.subtitle: The very long reach of Winston Churchill -- and how the British government is remaking copyright law.
episodes.description: The very long reach of Winston Churchill -- and how the British government is remaking copyright law.
episodes.title: Who Owns the Words That Come Out of Your Mouth?

episodes.subtitle: Why do Hall of Fame inductees, Oscar winners, and Nobel laureates outlive their peers?
episodes.description: Why do Hall of Fame inductees, Oscar winners, and Nobel laureates outlive their peers?
episodes.title: How to Live Longer

episodes.subtitle: Levitt and Dubner answer your questions about driving, sneezing, and ladies’ nights. Plus a remembrance of Levitt’s sister Linda.
episodes.description: Levitt and Dubner answer your questions about driving, sneezing, and ladies’ nights. Plus a remembrance of Levitt’s sister Linda.
episodes.title: How Did “Freakonomics” Get Its Name? … and Other FREAK-quently Asked Questions

episodes.subtitle: It's harder than you'd think to measure the value of a boss. But some enterprising economists have done just that -- and the news is good.
episodes.description: It's harder than you'd think to measure the value of a boss. But some enterprising economists have done just that -- and the news is good.
episodes.title: How Much Does a Good Boss Really Matter?

episodes.subtitle: Dubner's childhood home goes from sacred to profane -- and then back again.
episodes.description: Dubner's childhood home goes from sacred to profane -- and then back again.
episodes.title: The House of Dreams

episodes.subtitle: Who better than an economist to help with your shopping list?
episodes.description: Who better than an economist to help with your shopping list?
episodes.title: Have a Very Homo Economicus Christmas

episodes.subtitle: College, at its best, is about learning to think. Stephen Dubner chats up three of his former professors who made the magic happen.
episodes.description: College, at its best, is about learning to think. Stephen Dubner chats up three of his former professors who made the magic happen.
episodes.title: The Things They Taught Me

episodes.subtitle: Economists are a notoriously self-interested bunch. But a British outfit called Pro Bono Economics is giving away its services to selected charities.
episodes.description: Economists are a notoriously self-interested bunch. But a British outfit called Pro Bono Economics is giving away its services to selected charities.
episodes.title: Free-conomics

episodes.subtitle: There are enough management consultants these days to form a small nation. But what do they actually do? And does it work?
episodes.description: There are enough management consultants these days to form a small nation. But what do they actually do? And does it work?
episodes.title: I Consult, Therefore I Am

episodes.subtitle: Adding more train and bus lines looks like an environmental slam dunk. Until you start to do the math.
episodes.description: Adding more train and bus lines looks like an environmental slam dunk. Until you start to do the math.
episodes.title: Mass Transit Hysteria

episodes.subtitle: Turkey sex and chicken wings, selling souls and swapping organs, the power of the president and the price of wine: these are a few of our favorite things.
episodes.description: Turkey sex and chicken wings, selling souls and swapping organs, the power of the president and the price of wine: these are a few of our favorite things.
episodes.title: Our 100th Episode!

episodes.subtitle: Is it as simple as going to the richest neighborhood you can find? Of course not ...
episodes.description: Is it as simple as going to the richest neighborhood you can find? Of course not ...
episodes.title: How to Maximize Your Halloween Candy Haul

episodes.subtitle: Politicians tell voters exactly what they want to hear, even when it makes no sense. Which is pretty much all the time.
episodes.description: Politicians tell voters exactly what they want to hear, even when it makes no sense. Which is pretty much all the time.
episodes.title: We the Sheeple

episodes.subtitle: We rely on polls and surveys to tell us how people will behave in the future. Too bad they're completely unreliable.
episodes.description: We rely on polls and surveys to tell us how people will behave in the future. Too bad they're completely unreliable.
episodes.title: Lying to Ourselves

episodes.subtitle: When you want to get rid of a nasty pest, one obvious solution comes to mind: just offer a cash reward. But be careful -- because nothing backfires quite like a bounty.
episodes.description: When you want to get rid of a nasty pest, one obvious solution comes to mind: just offer a cash reward. But be careful -- because nothing backfires quite like a bounty.
episodes.title: The Cobra Effect

episodes.subtitle: Sure, we love our computers and all the rest of our digital toys. But when it comes to real economic gains, can we ever match old-school innovations like the automobile and electricity?
episodes.description: Sure, we love our computers and all the rest of our digital toys. But when it comes to real economic gains, can we ever match old-school innovations like the automobile and electricity?
episodes.title: Why America’s Economic Growth May Be (Shh!) Over

episodes.subtitle: Trying to go rustic by baking, brewing, and knitting at home can be terribly inefficient. And that's a wonderful thing.
episodes.description: Trying to go rustic by baking, brewing, and knitting at home can be terribly inefficient. And that's a wonderful thing.
episodes.title: The Tale of the $15 Tomato

episodes.subtitle: The data show that poker is indeed a game of skill, not chance, and a Federal judge agrees. So why are players still being treated like criminals?
episodes.description: The data show that poker is indeed a game of skill, not chance, and a Federal judge agrees. So why are players still being treated like criminals?
episodes.title: Why Online Poker Should Be Legal

episodes.subtitle: What "Sleep No More" and the Stanford Prison Experiment tell us about who we really are.
episodes.description: What "Sleep No More" and the Stanford Prison Experiment tell us about who we really are.
episodes.title: Fear Thy Nature

episodes.subtitle: Binge drinking is a big problem at college football games. Oliver Luck -- father of No. 1 NFL pick Andrew, and the athletic director at West Virginia University -- had an unusual idea to help solve it.
episodes.description: Binge drinking is a big problem at college football games. Oliver Luck -- father of No. 1 NFL pick Andrew, and the athletic director at West Virginia University -- had an unusual idea to help solve it.
episodes.title: Can Selling Beer Cut Down on Public Drunkenness?

episodes.subtitle: What we know -- and don't know -- about the gazillions of dollars that never show up on anyone's books.
episodes.description: What we know -- and don't know -- about the gazillions of dollars that never show up on anyone's books.
episodes.title: How Deep Is the Shadow Economy?

episodes.subtitle: If you think working from home offers too many distractions, just think about what happens at the office.
episodes.description: If you think working from home offers too many distractions, just think about what happens at the office.
episodes.title: There’s Cake in the Breakroom!

episodes.subtitle: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?
episodes.description: College tends to make people happier, healthier, and wealthier. But how?
episodes.title: Freakonomics Goes to College, Part 2

episodes.subtitle: We know that summertime brings far too many fatal accidents. But you may be surprised if you dig into the numbers.
episodes.description: We know that summertime brings far too many fatal accidents. But you may be surprised if you dig into the numbers.
episodes.title: The Season of Death

episodes.subtitle: What's a college degree really worth these days?
episodes.description: What's a college degree really worth these days?
episodes.title: Freakonomics Goes to College, Part 1

episodes.subtitle: Do host cities really get the benefits their boosters promise, or are they just engaging in some fiscal gymnastics?
episodes.description: Do host cities really get the benefits their boosters promise, or are they just engaging in some fiscal gymnastics?
episodes.title: Olympian Economics

episodes.subtitle: What happens to your reputation when you're no longer around to defend it?
episodes.description: What happens to your reputation when you're no longer around to defend it?
episodes.title: Legacy of a Jerk

episodes.subtitle: If we want our kids to thrive in school, maybe we should just pay them.
episodes.description: If we want our kids to thrive in school, maybe we should just pay them.
episodes.title: What's Wrong With Cash for Grades?

episodes.subtitle: Levitt and Dubner answer your FREAK-quently Asked Questions about junk food, insurance, and how to make an economist happy.
episodes.description: Levitt and Dubner answer your FREAK-quently Asked Questions about junk food, insurance, and how to make an economist happy.
episodes.title: Please Steal My Car

episodes.subtitle: Once a week, the British Prime Minister goes before the House of Commons for a lightning round of hard questions. Should the U.S. give it a try?
episodes.description: Once a week, the British Prime Minister goes before the House of Commons for a lightning round of hard questions. Should the U.S. give it a try?
episodes.title: Star-Spangled Banter?

episodes.subtitle: How using peer pressure -- and good, old-fashioned shame -- can push people to do the right thing.
episodes.description: How using peer pressure -- and good, old-fashioned shame -- can push people to do the right thing.
episodes.title: Riding the Herd Mentality

episodes.subtitle: Paying workers as little as possible seems smart -- unless you can make more money by paying them more.
episodes.description: Paying workers as little as possible seems smart -- unless you can make more money by paying them more.
episodes.title: A Cheap Employee Is … a Cheap Employee

episodes.subtitle: To feed 7 billion people while protecting the environment, it would seem that going local is a no-brainer -- until you start looking at the numbers.

episodes.description: The NBA’s superstars are suddenly sporting Urkel glasses -- but is it more than a fashion statement?
episodes.title: Playing the Nerd Card

episodes.subtitle: How American food so got bad -- and why it's getting so much better.
episodes.description: How American food so got bad -- and why it's getting so much better.

episodes.subtitle: In a world where nearly everything is for sale, is it always okay to buy what isn’t yours?
episodes.description: In a world where nearly everything is for sale, is it always okay to buy what isn’t yours?
episodes.title: Soul Possession

episodes.subtitle: At a time when people worry about every mile their food must travel, why is it okay to import most of our cut flowers from thousands of miles away?
episodes.description: At a time when people worry about every mile their food must travel, why is it okay to import most of our cut flowers from thousands of miles away?

episodes.subtitle: What do you do when smart people keep making stupid mistakes? And: are we a nation of financial illiterates?

episodes.title: Lottery Loopholes and Deadly Doctors

episodes.subtitle: A new study says that yes, it is -- but try telling that to the United Nations officials who are preaching sustainability practices.
episodes.description: A new study says that yes, it is -- but try telling that to the United Nations officials who are preaching sustainability practices.
episodes.title: Is Good Corporate Citizenship Also Good for the Bottom Line?

episodes.subtitle: Does the future of food lie in its past – or inside a tank of liquid nitrogen? Also: how anti-social can you be on a social network?
episodes.description: Does the future of food lie in its past – or inside a tank of liquid nitrogen? Also: how anti-social can you be on a social network?

episodes.subtitle: If any other product failed 94 percent of the time, you’d probably stop using it. So why do we put up with burglar alarms?
episodes.description: If any other product failed 94 percent of the time, you’d probably stop using it. So why do we put up with burglar alarms?

episodes.description: How much does the President of the United States really matter? And: where did all the hitchhikers go? A pair of "attribution errors."

episodes.subtitle: Women hold fewer than one in 10 patents. Why? And what are we missing out on?
episodes.description: Women hold fewer than one in 10 patents. Why? And what are we missing out on?
episodes.title: The Patent Gap

episodes.subtitle: Is booing an act of verbal vandalism or the last true expression of democracy? And: when you drive a Prius, are you guilty of “conspicuous conservation”?
episodes.description: Is booing an act of verbal vandalism or the last true expression of democracy? And: when you drive a Prius, are you guilty of “conspicuous conservation”?

episodes.subtitle: Isn’t it time to admit that the U.S. economy doesn’t have a commander in chief?
episodes.description: Isn’t it time to admit that the U.S. economy doesn’t have a commander in chief?
episodes.title: It’s Not the President, Stupid

episodes.subtitle: Do more expensive wines taste better? And: what does one little rodent in a salad say about a restaurant’s future?
episodes.description: Do more expensive wines taste better? And: what does one little rodent in a salad say about a restaurant’s future?
episodes.title: The Days of Wine and Mouses

episodes.subtitle: Measuring workplace morale -- and how to game the sick-day system.
episodes.description: Measuring workplace morale -- and how to game the sick-day system.
episodes.title: The Dilbert Index?

episodes.subtitle: The left and the right blame each other for pretty much everything, including slanted media coverage. Can they both be right?
episodes.description: The left and the right blame each other for pretty much everything, including slanted media coverage. Can they both be right?
episodes.title: How Biased Is Your Media?

episodes.subtitle: A look at some non-obvious ways to lose weight.
episodes.description: A look at some non-obvious ways to lose weight.
episodes.title: Does This Recession Make Me Look Fat?

episodes.subtitle: A commitment device forces you to be the person you really want to be. What could possibly go wrong?
episodes.description: A commitment device forces you to be the person you really want to be. What could possibly go wrong?

episodes.subtitle: A football cheat sheet to help you sound like the smartest person at the party.
episodes.description: A football cheat sheet to help you sound like the smartest person at the party.

episodes.subtitle: Education is the surest solution to a lot of problems. Except when it’s not.
episodes.description: Education is the surest solution to a lot of problems. Except when it’s not.
episodes.title: What Do Hand-Washing and Financial Illiteracy Have in Common?

episodes.subtitle: We all know the answer is yes. But the data -- and Rudy Giuliani -- say no.
episodes.description: We all know the answer is yes. But the data -- and Rudy Giuliani -- say no.
episodes.title: Does Money Really Buy Elections?

episodes.subtitle: Levitt and Dubner answer your FREAK-quently Asked Questions about certifying politicians, irrational fears, and the toughest three words in the English language.
episodes.description: Levitt and Dubner answer your FREAK-quently Asked Questions about certifying politicians, irrational fears, and the toughest three words in the English language.
episodes.title: Why Is “I Don’t Know” So Hard to Say?

episodes.subtitle: We know it's terribly dangerous to drive drunk. But heading home on foot isn't the solution.
episodes.description: We know it's terribly dangerous to drive drunk. But heading home on foot isn't the solution.

episodes.subtitle: The thrill of customization, via Pandora and a radical new teaching method
episodes.description: The thrill of customization, via Pandora and a radical new teaching method
episodes.title: How Is a Bad Radio Station Like Our Public-School System? (Encore)

episodes.subtitle: Tyler Cowen points fingers. There's plenty of blame to go around.
episodes.description: Tyler Cowen points fingers. There's plenty of blame to go around.
episodes.title: How American Food Got So Bad

episodes.subtitle: Clever ways to not waste our waste.
episodes.description: Clever ways to not waste our waste.

episodes.subtitle: The science of charity, with economist John List.
episodes.description: The science of charity, with economist John List.
episodes.title: What Makes a Donor Donate?

episodes.subtitle: There’s a nasty secret about hot-button topics like global warming: knowledge is not always power.
episodes.description: There’s a nasty secret about hot-button topics like global warming: knowledge is not always power.
episodes.title: The Truth Is Out There…Isn’t It?

episodes.subtitle: Our appetite for breast meat renders our holiday birds unable to reproduce.
episodes.description: Our appetite for breast meat renders our holiday birds unable to reproduce.
episodes.title: Unnatural Turkeys

episodes.subtitle: Is booing an act of verbal vandalism—or the last true expression of democracy?
episodes.description: Is booing an act of verbal vandalism—or the last true expression of democracy?
episodes.title: Boo…Who?

episodes.subtitle: On Election Day, most people focus on the obvious winners and losers -- that is, the candidates. But we went looking for some of the strange side effects that elections produce.
episodes.description: On Election Day, most people focus on the obvious winners and losers -- that is, the candidates. But we went looking for some of the strange side effects that elections produce.
episodes.title: Wildfires, Cops, and Keggers

episodes.subtitle: We are constantly wowed by new technologies and policies meant to make childbirth better. But beware the unintended consequences.
episodes.description: We are constantly wowed by new technologies and policies meant to make childbirth better. But beware the unintended consequences.
episodes.title: Misadventures in Baby-Making

episodes.subtitle: High-stakes testing has produced some rotten apples. But they can be caught.
episodes.description: High-stakes testing has produced some rotten apples. But they can be caught.
episodes.title: Those Cheating Teachers!

episodes.subtitle: Did we needlessly scare ourselves into ditching a good thing? And, with millions of cars driving around with no passengers, should we be rooting for a renaissance?
episodes.description: Did we needlessly scare ourselves into ditching a good thing? And, with millions of cars driving around with no passengers, should we be rooting for a renaissance?
episodes.title: Where Have All the Hitchhikers Gone?

episodes.subtitle: The world is a more peaceful place today that at any time in history -- by a long, long shot.
episodes.description: The world is a more peaceful place today that at any time in history -- by a long, long shot.
episodes.title: The Decline and Fall of Violence

episodes.subtitle: You know the saying: a winner never quits and a quitter never wins. To which Freakonomics Radio says … Are you sure?
episodes.description: You know the saying: a winner never quits and a quitter never wins. To which Freakonomics Radio says … Are you sure?
episodes.title: The Upside of Quitting

episodes.subtitle: Human beings love to predict the future, but we're quite terrible at it. So how about punishing all those bad predictions?
episodes.description: Human beings love to predict the future, but we're quite terrible at it. So how about punishing all those bad predictions?
episodes.title: The Folly of Prediction

episodes.subtitle: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.
episodes.description: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.
episodes.title: The Suicide Paradox

episodes.subtitle: Think you know how much parents matter? Think again. Economists crunch the numbers to learn the ROI on child-rearing.
episodes.description: Think you know how much parents matter? Think again. Economists crunch the numbers to learn the ROI on child-rearing.
episodes.title: The Economist’s Guide to Parenting

episodes.subtitle: We worship the tradition of handing off a family business to the next generation. But is that really such a good idea?
episodes.description: We worship the tradition of handing off a family business to the next generation. But is that really such a good idea?
episodes.title: The Church of "Scionology"

episodes.subtitle: In restaurants and in life, bad things happen. But what happens next is just as important.
episodes.description: In restaurants and in life, bad things happen. But what happens next is just as important.
episodes.title: Mouse in the Salad

episodes.subtitle: "Conspicuous conservation" is about showing off your environmental bona fides. In other words, if you lean green, there's extra value in being seen leaning green.
episodes.description: "Conspicuous conservation" is about showing off your environmental bona fides. In other words, if you lean green, there's extra value in being seen leaning green.
episodes.title: Hey Baby, Is That a Prius You're Driving?

episodes.subtitle: Freakonomics Radio hits the road, and plays some Quiz Bowl
episodes.description: Freakonomics Radio hits the road, and plays some Quiz Bowl
episodes.title: Live From St. Paul!

episodes.subtitle: What did Levitt and Dubner learn as kids from their dads?
episodes.description: What did Levitt and Dubner learn as kids from their dads?
episodes.title: Things Our Fathers Gave Us

episodes.subtitle: Who is likelier to get to the fugitive first? When a fugitive is on the run, it’s not only the police he has to worry about. A bounty hunter could be coming after him, too.
episodes.description: Who is likelier to get to the fugitive first? When a fugitive is on the run, it’s not only the police he has to worry about. A bounty hunter could be coming after him, too.
episodes.title: To Catch a Fugitive

episodes.subtitle: What’s it like to wake up one day and realize Dad is a multi-billionaire? That's what happened to Warren Buffett’s son Peter -- who then started to think about whether or not to join the family business.
episodes.description: What’s it like to wake up one day and realize Dad is a multi-billionaire? That's what happened to Warren Buffett’s son Peter -- who then started to think about whether or not to join the family business.
episodes.title: Growing Up Buffett

episodes.subtitle: Does Las Vegas increase your risk of suicide? A researcher embeds himself in the city where Americans are most likely to kill themselves.
episodes.description: Does Las Vegas increase your risk of suicide? A researcher embeds himself in the city where Americans are most likely to kill themselves.
episodes.title: Gambling With Your Life

episodes.subtitle: In our second round of FREAK-quently Asked Questions, Steve Levitt answers some queries from listeners and readers.
episodes.description: In our second round of FREAK-quently Asked Questions, Steve Levitt answers some queries from listeners and readers.
episodes.title: Does College Still Matter? And Other Freaky Questions Answered ...

episodes.subtitle: It won’t work for everyone, but there’s a cheap, quick, and simple way to lift some students’ grades.
episodes.description: It won’t work for everyone, but there’s a cheap, quick, and simple way to lift some students’ grades.
episodes.title: Smarter Kids at 10 Bucks a Pop

episodes.subtitle: We talk to a U.S. Geological Survey physicist about the science -- and folly -- of predicting earthquakes. There are lots of known knowns; and, fortunately, not too many unknown unknowns. But it's the known unknowns -- the timing of the next Big One -- t
episodes.description: We talk to a U.S. Geological Survey physicist about the science -- and folly -- of predicting earthquakes. There are lots of known knowns; and, fortunately, not too many unknown unknowns. But it's the known unknowns -- the timing of the next Big One -- that are the most dangerous.
episodes.title: Why Can’t We Predict Earthquakes?

episodes.subtitle: Fire deaths in the U.S. have fallen 90 percent over the past 100 years, a great and greatly underappreciated gain. How did it happen -- and could we ever get to zero?
episodes.description: Fire deaths in the U.S. have fallen 90 percent over the past 100 years, a great and greatly underappreciated gain. How did it happen -- and could we ever get to zero?
episodes.title: Death by Fire? Probably Not

episodes.subtitle: For decades, GDP has been the yardstick for measuring living standards around the world. Martha Nussbaum would rather use something that actually works.
episodes.description: For decades, GDP has been the yardstick for measuring living standards around the world. Martha Nussbaum would rather use something that actually works.
episodes.title: The Health of Nations

episodes.subtitle: To get a lot of followers on Twitter, do you need to follow a lot of other Tweeps? And if not, why not?
episodes.description: To get a lot of followers on Twitter, do you need to follow a lot of other Tweeps? And if not, why not?
episodes.title: Is Twitter a Two-Way Street?

episodes.subtitle: Since the beginning of civilization, we’ve thought that human waste was worthless and dangerous. What if we were wrong?
episodes.description: Since the beginning of civilization, we’ve thought that human waste was worthless and dangerous. What if we were wrong?
episodes.title: The Power of Poop

episodes.subtitle: Five things you don’t know about the NFL labor standoff
episodes.description: Five things you don’t know about the NFL labor standoff
episodes.title: Millionaires vs. Billionaires

episodes.subtitle: Could it be that cities are "our greatest invention" -- that, despite a reputation as black-soot-spewing engines of doom, they in fact make us richer, smarter, happier and (believe it!) greener?
episodes.description: Could it be that cities are "our greatest invention" -- that, despite a reputation as black-soot-spewing engines of doom, they in fact make us richer, smarter, happier and (believe it!) greener?
episodes.title: Why Cities Rock

episodes.subtitle: It's not about how much something hurts -- it's how you remember the pain. This week, lessons on pain from the New York City subway, the professional hockey rink, and a landmark study of colonoscopy patients. So have a listen; we promise, it won't hurt a
episodes.description: It's not about how much something hurts -- it's how you remember the pain. This week, lessons on pain from the New York City subway, the professional hockey rink, and a landmark study of colonoscopy patients. So have a listen; we promise, it won't hurt a bit.
episodes.title: Bring on the Pain!

episodes.subtitle: What do a computer hacker, an Indiana farm boy, and Napoleon Bonaparte have in common? The past, present, and future of food science.
episodes.description: What do a computer hacker, an Indiana farm boy, and Napoleon Bonaparte have in common? The past, present, and future of food science.
episodes.title: Waiter, There’s a Physicist in My Soup! (Part 2)

episodes.subtitle: The "molecular gastronomy" movement -- which gets a bump in visibility next month with the publication of the mammoth cookbook "Modernist Cuisine" -- is all about bringing more science into the kitchen. In many ways, it's the opposite of the "slow food"
episodes.description: The "molecular gastronomy" movement -- which gets a bump in visibility next month with the publication of the mammoth cookbook "Modernist Cuisine" -- is all about bringing more science into the kitchen. In many ways, it's the opposite of the "slow food" movement. In this episode, you'll hear chieftains from the two camps square off: Alice Waters for the slow foodies and Nathan Myhrvold for the mad scientists. Bon appetit!
episodes.title: Waiter, There’s a Physicist in My Soup! (Part 1)

episodes.subtitle: Levitt and Dubner field questions from the public and hold forth on everything from dating strategies and rock-and-roll accordion music to whether different nations have different economic identities. Oh, and also: is it worthwhile to vote?
episodes.description: Levitt and Dubner field questions from the public and hold forth on everything from dating strategies and rock-and-roll accordion music to whether different nations have different economic identities. Oh, and also: is it worthwhile to vote?
episodes.title: Freakonomics FAQ, No. 1

description: In their books "Freakonomics," "SuperFreakonomics" and "Think Like a Freak", Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner explore "the hidden side of everything," telling stories about cheating schoolteachers and eating champions while teaching us all to think a bit more creatively, rationally, and productively. The Freakonomics Radio podcast, hosted by Dubner, carries on that tradition with weekly episodes. Prepare to be enlightened, engaged, perhaps enraged, and definitely surprised.
title: Freakonomics Radio
